div.head: CORRESPONDENCE
LETTER FROM Mr. ALEXANDRE DUMAS.
div.p: There is a Revue Coloniale which differs from the Revue des Colonies, not only in its title, but in its principles and the purpose of its publication. In mentioning this opposition; we do not mean to blame our adversaries. Everyone is perfectly free to write for or against the spirit of reform; but the following letter, which is addressed to us by one of the century’s greatest literary figures, compels us to acknowledge this Revue Coloniale, which publishes opinions contrary to ours, and this Review has cited M. Alexandre Dumas among its collaborators.

div.head: Mr. Editor of the Revue des Colonies.
div.p: “Would you mind correcting in one of your next issues an error which I see committed in my regard on the cover of the Revue Coloniale; Revue Coloniale; they announce that they will be publishing poems by me in one of their upcoming issues. First of all, I do little poetry, except in the theater; and I did not promise anything to the Revue Coloniale, which did not ask me for anything. All my sympathies, on the contrary, are instinctively and nationally for the adversaries of the principles defended by the Gentlemen of the Revue Coloniale; this is what I wish to be made perfectly clear, not only in France, but wherever I have brothers in race and friends of color.
